body:
What do you mean unable to train your own dataset without the .pkl? If it exists, it will load it. Otherwise, it will create one from your dataset.

Whether you have it or not will not result in poor training. The only difference is having to parse the dataset's annotations again.

If it has generated a .pkl file already and you change your dataset (Add images/annotations or make changes to them) You should delete your .pkl file.

I guess this is the problem, it is not generating a .pkl file when it does not exists. How do you wrote your config file with a cache_name = "" or just deleted it? 

I tried this two actions and it is always generating error for me.
I alse created a blank .pkl file and uses it as cache_name parameter, but also got an error.

What error do you get?

I don't work with the .pkl personally as I'm constantly updating my dataset, as such, I commented out that part of the code.

I commented out the part of the code that used it, as you suggested, and now I am able to train it. Thank you for your help! :)

Another topic, are you familiar with the best parameters to train an object detection that would search for small objects in pictures? I am trying to train a model to find small numbers in pictures. For now my I changed my dataset to 32x32 images, but I am not sure about witch grid_scales, obj_scale, noob_scale, xywh_scale and class_scale I should use. 

For now I am using the default one:

 "grid_scales":          [1,1,1],
        "obj_scale":            5,
        "noobj_scale":          1,
        "xywh_scale":           1,
        "class_scale":   1

What would you suggest?

thank you

It actually depends on your dataset. To configure it nicely, you also have to understand the YOLO v3 architecture. Below are some questions and some ideas on how to optimize (without me knowing your data)

Grid scales:
Are your images really 32x32? Are the numbers like 1x1, 5x5, 10x10 (These are just random sizes)?

You have to understand the 3 scales that YOLO work on. The first scale being 32 times smaller than the input. So if your images are 32x32,
- First scale, prediction on 1x1 feature maps.
- Second scale, prediction on 2x2 feature maps.
- Third scale, prediction on 4x4 feature maps.

I'm actually curious as to what your generated anchors are like, because it probably will look like  mostly 0s imo lol. I certainly hope not. If there are 0s, it means that those anchors are useless.

To modify this, you should look at which scale are you most dependent on. If they're all equal, you value all 3 scales the same. If you increase the scale, you value that particular scale more and its loss will be higher making the model try to optimize the weights for that.

I'm using [3,2,1] personally. My images are 256x256 and I have plenty of small objects but some medium sized and occasionally large ones.

Object scale:
Are you getting lots of false positives? If so, you might want to increase this, otherwise keep it at 1.

I have this at 3.

No object scale:
Are you getting lots of false negatives? If so, you might want to increase this, otherwise keep it at 1.

I have this at 1.

X, Y, width, height scale:
Are your predictions not centered and smaller or larger than what they should be? If so, you might want to increase this, otherwise keep it at 1.
Give the predictions some leeway though (Do manual visual checks), as we can't expect 100%.

I have this at 3.

Class scale:
Are the prediction boxes correct but having a lower classification score and resulting in a wrong classification? If so, you might want to increase this, otherwise keep it at 1.

I have this at 1, but I am applying this on a single class. As such, it does not matter what this number is for me.

---
If your images can't get larger (I'm assuming these are the best images (32x32) you have and not scaled down to increase training time etc), YOLO v3 would not be great for you.

You can make changes to the architecture, like reducing the scaling from 32 times to say 8 times. This however requires you to understand the architecture, remove bits etc (Much easier than adding another scale,  and that was a pain in my ass and didn't work well for me). 

I hope this helps you! And anyone else that ends up reading this.

Hello @darjoo 

I am really pleased with your answers. It will help me a lot. 

**Grid scales:**

Indeed I scaled down all my images to increase training time, so I guess it will have to do it again but to a bigger sizer. Although I have scaled down to 32x32 me anchors are as fallows, so maybe I will get some good results after this first training. 

 **"anchors":              [14,20, 38,82, 51,88, 61,79, 61,93, 74,85, 79,99, 141,227, 195,226]**

I dont know how to tell you witch scale I am most dependent on. I guess just when I see some results I will have this answer. Firts scale is for big objects, second for medium objects and third to detect small objects?

**Object scale:**
"Are you getting lots of false positives? If so, you might want to increase this, otherwise keep it at 1.""

Yes, I am o Resnet50. I will increase this value to train again there. Here (with Yolov3) I need more time to see the training results. 

Other topics will depend os this output, but I really appreciated your advices. 

About the architecture, I am definitely not going to change it. I will follow your advice and work changing the dataset and parameters.

Thank you
👍  :)

You're welcome @giovannicaprio.

Your anchors should be regenerated on the scaled down images & annotations. The anchors that are used do not get rescaled. It's not going to prevent the network from training properly but it'd be a little slower. But I'd recommend you use the original images just because you lose a lot of spatial information when you scale a image down.

Yes, you are right. The first scale is the largest, followed by medium and small objects.
One way to find out which scale is most important, you can take a look at this part in the generator.py, method __getitem__

```
for i in range(len(self.anchors)):
    anchor = self.anchors[i]
    iou    = bbox_iou(shifted_box, anchor)

    if max_iou < iou:
        max_anchor = anchor
        max_index  = i
        max_iou    = iou
```

You can include a counter to count the number of times a anchor is used and determine from there which is your most important to least important anchor. From that, you can see which scales should have higher weighting.

Good luck with training on your dataset :)

Awesome! I will take a peek. 

Thankyou
@giovannicaprio can you please tell which part did you comment out exactly from the code as i'm experiencing the same issue for not having the .pkl file for our own training dataset

![v3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37379333/41080768-940d2734-6a45-11e8-822e-6ccca2e00902.PNG)
@giovannicaprio I've been getting this error when training on my images. My input image size is 1920 x 1080. What is the use of min_input_size and max_input_size in the config.json. Which value should we set it for and suppose our dataset is of variable size then which value to set for min_input_size and max_input_size in the config.json?

@pratt-datar If you take a look at the error messages above, you would notice that it is unable to read find your image files. Double check that they exist in that path, try to load them in with cv2 in a jupyter notebook for verification. I had this issue before but I do not remember how I resolved it.

Take a look at issue #92 regarding the input sizes, I just replied there.

Your images are way too large to train on imo. I'd say, go as small as possible without risking the loss important of data. Important being, if your objects are really small in 1920x1080, resizing that to half the size makes them pretty much tiny to nothing.
If you can split that 1920x1080 into smaller chunks, great. Otherwise consider resizing them manually or just allowing the generator with cv2 do the resizing for you.

Thank you so much but I cross checked that images are in the respected
folder,  still that thing is coming that it is unable to find those images.
